climbs.name: Pitfall
climbs.fa: Herb Laeger, Rich Perch, and Jim Beyer, November 1986

content.description:
This south-facing route is visible from the parking lot and is in the sun most of the day.

Steep, slightly run-out slab climbing on excellent brown patina. Two out of five stars.

The crux on this route comes right off the first bolt, but the whole route is strenuous until you join The Gash (.10a) at the end. It is possible to enter the crack earlier or later, but I'm not sure it changes the overall difficulty much.
content.protection: 4 bolts. A piece of gear at the start (small cam, not very good) protects getting to and clipping the first bolt and is probably a good idea. An optional cam can be placed in the finishing crack if desired. No fixed anchors on top; natural gear to 3 inches and slings are needed to build a toprope anchor.
content.location:
This is the 4 bolt route on the east side of the rock, around the corner from

Pitfall

.

Getting down is a little treacherous; it looks like it may be possible to climb up and over the top where Betty Gravel is and descend, but it is also possible to descend via a crack/chimney past the Pitfall face. The latter option is filled with kitty litter and is not recommended. I can't remember if the Pitfall anchor is accessible or not; it may have been that I didn't have any spare webbing to replace the ancient sunbleached tat that exists up there currently. In any case use caution with any option.

content.description: Steep opening moves lead up and sorta left on good holds.  The top out is the probable crux as some actual big moves must be done to grab the top jug and do the summit mantel.
content.protection: Top rope.  I'll check the current anchor situation and update this entry.
content.location: This route is on a small-ish boulder in front of and to the right of Pitfall.  The start is steep and bouldery with a pumpier than it ought to be feel.

content.description: This is a crack climb located on the face to the right of Pitfall/Cockpit face. It varies from finger to hand, and ends at a 2 bolt loweroff. The climbing is good.

climbs.name: The Gay Germans
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Tucker Tech, Rick Thompson

content.description: This route climbs the outside left edge of Pitted Rock. The climb faces the trail into The Real Hidden Valley. 3 bolts lead to a short crack and a 2 bolt anchor on top.
content.protection: QDs for the bolts, and a few small to med cams for the crack.
content.location: Outside left edge of Pitted Rock, which is located just above the parking lot for the Real Hidden Valley.

content.description: This is a coarse, awkward, strenuous crack climb.  If you don't mind coarse rock, it's a lot of fun.  Liebacking up a flake, followed by some thin hands jamming, takes you to a stance on a steep face.  A long crux move leads up to flared hand jamming and an exit to the top.
content.location: This is on the east face of Pitted Rock.  It is a left-leaning crack, which meets Pit Slut at the top.

climbs.name: Cockpit
climbs.fa: (TR) Bob Gaines et.al,  First Lead: Todd Gordon, Tucker Tech, Greg Epperson, Resa Ashbachar

content.description: This route is the right edge to the right of Pitfall. Climb up past bolts to the run-out finish of Pitfall.  Not a trad climb because all you need is quick draws, but not a sport climb because of the run-out. It's a bolt protected face climb with a run-out.

Thin-ish handcrack up a right-facing dihedral located to the left of Hurricane.  Finish by traversing right to the bolted rap rings atop Hurricane, or continue slightly left up a chimney to the rap anchor atop Pitfall.

One could also lower or scramble down into the pit below the boulder ledge start, to double the length of dihedral crackin' fun.
content.protection: Single rack to 3", bolted rap anchor.
